anns.prefix: ABSTRACT
anns.postfix: , a representative polyether ionophore, has been successfully applied in veterinary medicine and animal husbandry and also displays promising potential for cancer therapy.

anns.prefix: Nevertheless, the regulatory system governing
anns.postfix: biosynthesis remains obscure.

anns.prefix: Here, we identified two conserved (lodR2 and lodR3) and one variable (lodR1, found only in Streptomyces sp. strain FXJ1.172) putative regulatory genes through a comparison of the
anns.postfix: biosynthetic gene cluster (lod) from Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172 with those (las and lsd) from Streptomyces lasalocidi.

anns.prefix: Gene disruption experiments demonstrated that both lodR1 and lodR3 positively regulate
anns.postfix: biosynthesis in Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172, while lodR2 plays a negative regulatory role.

anns.prefix: The repression of lodAB–lodC by LodR1 likely boosts
anns.postfix: biosynthesis.

anns.prefix: Furthermore, LodR2 and LodE constitute a repressor-activator system that senses changes in intracellular
anns.postfix: concentrations and coordinates its biosynthesis.

anns.prefix: Comparative and parallel functional analyses of the homologous genes in S.
anns.postfix: i ATCC 31180T confirmed the conserved roles of lodR2, lodE, and lodR3 in controlling lasalocid biosynthesis.

anns.prefix: Overall, our findings demonstrate that
anns.postfix: biosynthesis is tightly controlled by both conserved and variable regulators, providing valuable guidance for further improving lasalocid production.

anns.prefix: IMPORTANCE Compared to its elaborated biosynthetic pathway, the regulation of
anns.postfix: biosynthesis remains obscure.

anns.prefix: Here, we characterize the roles of regulatory genes in
anns.postfix: biosynthetic gene clusters of two distinct Streptomyces species and identify a conserved repressor-activator system, LodR2–LodE, which could sense changes in the concentration of lasalocid and coordinate its biosynthesis with self-resistance.

anns.prefix: Furthermore, in parallel, we verify that the regulatory system identified in a new Streptomyces isolate is valid in the industrial
anns.postfix: producer and thus applicable for the construction of high-yield strains.
(4), one of the seven currently marketed carboxylic polyether ionophores, has been validated as a classical anticoccidial drug for poultry and a growth promoter in ruminants (5, 6).

selectively inhibits intracellular sporozoites while remaining relatively noninjurious to the host cell, and it has biased antimicrobial activity against Gram-positive bacteria, whereas most Gram-negative strains are still refractory (7).

anns.prefix: Moreover,
anns.postfix: and its synthetic analogs have shown high antiproliferative activity against cancer cell lines and, simultaneously, lower cytotoxicity toward nontumor cells than cisplatin, which hints at their potential to be developed as candidates for cancer treatment (2, 3, 9, 10).
(4), one of the seven currently marketed carboxylic polyether ionophores, has been validated as a classical anticoccidial drug for poultry and a growth promoter in ruminants (5, 6).

selectively inhibits intracellular sporozoites while remaining relatively noninjurious to the host cell, and it has biased antimicrobial activity against Gram-positive bacteria, whereas most Gram-negative strains are still refractory (7).

anns.prefix: Moreover,
anns.postfix: and its synthetic analogs have shown high antiproliferative activity against cancer cell lines and, simultaneously, lower cytotoxicity toward nontumor cells than cisplatin, which hints at their potential to be developed as candidates for cancer treatment (2, 3, 9, 10).

anns.prefix: The biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) of
anns.postfix: (nig) and salinomycin (sln) both contain a single pathway-specific regulatory gene, and the overexpression of these genes greatly enhanced the production of the corresponding polyether ionophores (11, 12).

anns.prefix: The biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) of
anns.postfix: ericin (nig) and salinomycin (sln) both contain a single pathway-specific regulatory gene, and the overexpression of these genes greatly enhanced the production of the corresponding polyether ionophores (11, 12).

anns.prefix: The biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) of nigericin (nig) and
anns.postfix: (sln) both contain a single pathway-specific regulatory gene, and the overexpression of these genes greatly enhanced the production of the corresponding polyether ionophores (11, 12).

anns.prefix: Unlike nig and sln, the BGCs of
anns.postfix: (mon) and nanchangmycin (nan) each contain multiple regulatory genes that encode regulators belonging to diverse families, including LAL (large ATP-binding regulators of the LuxR family), SARP (Streptomyces antibiotic regulatory proteins), TetR, and AraC. These regulators form complex coregulatory cascades governing the biosynthesis of monensin and nanchangmycin (13, 14).

anns.prefix: Unlike nig and sln, the BGCs of monensin (mon) and
anns.postfix: (nan) each contain multiple regulatory genes that encode regulators belonging to diverse families, including LAL (large ATP-binding regulators of the LuxR family), SARP (Streptomyces antibiotic regulatory proteins), TetR, and AraC. These regulators form complex coregulatory cascades governing the biosynthesis of monensin and nanchangmycin (13, 14).

anns.prefix: In addition to the above-mentioned cluster-situated regulators (CSRs), the global transcriptional regulator DasR has also been proven to increase
anns.postfix: production in Streptomyces cinnamonensis (15).

anns.prefix: However, although the biosynthetic pathway for
anns.postfix: has been well elucidated (16), the regulatory mechanism in lasalocid production remains obscure, which hinders its titer improvement and further industrialization.

anns.postfix: (nan) each contain multiple regulatory genes that encode regulators belonging to diverse families, including LAL (large ATP-binding regulators of the LuxR family), SARP (Streptomyces antibiotic regulatory proteins), TetR, and AraC. anns.prefix: In addition to the above-mentioned cluster-situated regulators (CSRs), the global transcriptional regulator DasR has also been proven to increase
anns.postfix: production in Streptomyces cinnamonensis (15).

anns.prefix: However, although the biosynthetic pathway for
anns.postfix: has been well elucidated (16), the regulatory mechanism in lasalocid production remains obscure, which hinders its titer improvement and further industrialization.

anns.prefix: To date,
anns.postfix: BGCs have been cloned from two closely related strains of Streptomyces lasalocidi, ATCC 31180T (las) and ATCC 35851 (lsd) (22, 23), and were recently discovered from a potential novel species represented by red soil-derived Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172 (lod) (24–26).

anns.prefix: Here, to elucidate the pathway-specific regulatory mechanism in
anns.postfix: biosynthesis, we conducted comparative and parallel functional analyses of the regulatory genes from different lasalocid BGCs.

anns.prefix: We reveal that both the variable and conserved regulatory genes are functional in different
anns.postfix: BGCs, providing evidence for regulatory diversification.

anns.prefix: We also identified a conserved repressor-activator system composed of LodR2/Las3/Lsd6–7 (unless otherwise specified, the dash indicates a range) and LodE/Las2/Lsd5, which is important for the control of
anns.postfix: concentrations at appropriate levels in the producers.

anns.prefix: In our previous study, we identified a 76,167-bp putative
anns.postfix: gene cluster (lod [GenBank accession number KT591188]) from the genome sequence of Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172 (26).

anns.prefix: Bioinformatics analysis revealed that the cluster contains 22 open reading frames (ORFs), designated lodA–lodT. In this study, to unravel the regulatory mechanism of
anns.postfix: biosynthesis in different Streptomyces species, we first compared lod with the other two lasalocid gene clusters (las and lsd from S. lasalocidi strains).

anns.prefix: Three genes of the lod cluster are proposed to play a regulatory role in
anns.postfix: biosynthesis in Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172, including a variable gene (lodR1) and two conserved ones (lodR2 and lodR3).

anns.prefix: High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis of the culture extracts from these mutants revealed a substantial loss of
anns.postfix: production in the ΔlodR1 mutant and a complete loss in the ΔlodR3 mutant but a moderate increase in the ΔlodR2 mutant (Fig. 2).

anns.prefix: Complementation with lodR1, lodR2, and lodR3 (inserted into pSET152 and driven by PkasO*) in the corresponding mutants partially or completely restored
anns.postfix: production (Fig. 2).

anns.prefix: These results indicate that lodR1 and lodR3 positively regulate
anns.postfix: biosynthesis in Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172, while lodR2 plays a negative regulatory role.

anns.prefix: As expected, the constitutive expression of lodA–lodC resulted in a dramatic decrease in
anns.postfix: production in 31180-KABC (Fig. 4D).

anns.prefix: In contrast,
anns.postfix: production in 31180-R1ABC was comparable to that in the WT strain, which might be attributed to the inhibition of lodA–lodC expression by LodR1.

anns.prefix: These findings suggest that the variable genes lodR1 and lodA–lodC seem to function conservatively in
anns.postfix: biosynthesis in different Streptomyces species.

anns.postfix: i strains are used as industrially valuable lasalocid producers, and thus, the regulatory mechanism of their lasalocid biosynthesis is worth dissecting for the construction of high-yield strains.

anns.prefix: To verify the role of these genes in
anns.postfix: biosynthesis, the corresponding disruption mutants (Δlas2, Δlas3, and Δlas4) were constructed from the S. lasalocidi ATCC 31180T wild type (31180-WT).

anns.prefix: Compared to that of 31180-WT, the
anns.postfix: yield of the Δlas2 mutant was greatly reduced (from 33.8 to 4.7 mg/L), and that of the Δlas3 mutant was increased (from 33.8 to 112.5 mg/L), while lasalocid was no longer detected in the Δlas4 mutant (Fig. 7A).

anns.prefix: As a result, both the ΔlodR3 mutant cross-complemented with las4 and the Δlas4 mutant cross-complemented with lodR3 could restore
anns.postfix: production to the level of the WT strains (Fig. 7B).

anns.prefix: All of these results are consistent with those for Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172, indicating a conserved regulatory mechanism of
anns.postfix: biosynthesis in the two species.

anns.prefix: Based on the above-described regulatory studies, high-yield
anns.postfix: strains were constructed by overexpressing las4 in the Δlas3 mutant via a multicopy vector, pKC1139::PkasO*las4, or a single-site integrative vector, pSET152::PkasO*las4.

anns.prefix: The resultant mutants, Δlas3-1139-las4OE and Δlas3-152-las4OE, enhanced their
anns.postfix: yields by 5.1 and 6.8 times, respectively, compared to 31180-WT (Fig. 7A).

anns.prefix: Overall, by the simultaneous disruption of the negative regulatory gene las3 and the overexpression of the positive regulatory gene las4, we obtained high-yield strains with
anns.postfix: production of up to 230 mg/L. S. lasalocidi strains are used as industrially valuable lasalocid producers, and thus, the regulatory mechanism of their lasalocid biosynthesis is worth dissecting for the construction of high-yield strains.

anns.prefix: DISCUSSION DISCUSSION Multiple regulatory genes coexist in lasalocid BGCs, but they may not form the complex coregulatory cascade process seen in the biosynthesis of
anns.postfix: and nanchangmycin (13, 14).

anns.prefix: DISCUSSION DISCUSSION Multiple regulatory genes coexist in lasalocid BGCs, but they may not form the complex coregulatory cascade process seen in the biosynthesis of monensin and
Our results reveal that
anns.postfix: biosynthesis in different Streptomyces species is controlled by one variable and two conserved regulatory systems, providing an understanding of the regulatory diversification and mechanism.

anns.prefix: The presence of this variable locus in Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172 could be partially ascribed to the divergent evolution of the regulation of
anns.postfix: biosynthesis among streptomycetes.

anns.prefix: The lsd2 gene, encoding a putative IclR family protein (23), might also have a regulatory role in
anns.postfix: biosynthesis in S. lasalocidi ATCC 35851, albeit the whole sequence of lsd needs to be confirmed by genome sequencing.

anns.prefix: It was unexpected that the constitutive heterologous expression of lodA–lodC from Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172 also resulted in the diminished production of
anns.postfix: in S. lasalocidi ATCC 31180T.

anns.prefix: This result suggests that these ORFs exclusive to lod can play a general role in the regulation of
anns.postfix: biosynthesis in different Streptomyces species.

anns.prefix: Although we attributed the undisturbed
anns.postfix: production in the mutant strain 31180-R1ABC to the inhibition of lodA–lodC expression by LodR1, we cannot exclude another possibility, that all of these genes are not well expressed in the heterologous host, and more details are needed to further check whether the repression of the expression of lodA–lodC by LodR1 is functionally conserved in S. lasalocidi.

anns.prefix: Additionally, based on their proposed roles (Table 1), we presumed that lodA–lodC might be involved in the biosynthesis of an unknown molecule, which shares substrates with
anns.postfix: biosynthesis, thus leading to the reduced production of lasalocid.

anns.prefix: Our further work will focus on functional analyses of lodA, lodB, and lodC to determine how much of the reduced
anns.postfix: production in different strains is due to lodAB versus lodC and to uncover their repression mechanism in lasalocid biosynthesis.

anns.prefix: In this study, we demonstrate that
anns.postfix: specifically binds to the MarR family transcription repressor LodR2 and causes its dissociation from the promoter region of lodR2–lodE (Fig. 5B), thus activating the transcription of lodE. This finding coincides with the defining feature of MarR family regulators: they normally respond to specific ligands, resulting in attenuated DNA-binding activity and often the derepression of target gene transcription (38).

anns.prefix: Recently, a polyether antibiotic,
anns.postfix: , has also been proven to inhibit the DNA-binding activity of its cognate CSR CalR3, which subsequently initiates the expression of the calcimycin transporter-encoding gene calT (39).

anns.prefix: The transporter LodE is also crucial for
anns.postfix: biosynthesis because disruption of lodE results in reduced lasalocid production and an increased ratio of intracellular/extracellular lasalocid concentrations.

anns.prefix: It is noteworthy that the residual production of lasalocid in the ΔlodE mutant implies the existence of other efflux systems in the producer strain, as seen in the
anns.postfix: producer Streptomyces albus BK3-25 (40).
acts as an ionophore antibiotic, which facilitates cation transport across plasma membranes.

anns.postfix: BGCs highlights their indispensable role in the regulation of lasalocid biosynthesis.

anns.postfix: , monensin, and laidlomycin (a monensin analog) gene clusters, respectively (31, 41, 42).

When

anns.prefix: Subsequently, the strong expression of lodE, which encodes an antibiotic efflux pump, results in a drop in the intracellular
anns.postfix: concentration and then the continuous production of lasalocid.

anns.prefix: Thus, with the LodR2–LodE system, the concentration of
anns.postfix: in the producing strain is controlled at an appropriate level to avoid self-inhibition.

anns.prefix: Moreover, LodR1 positively regulates
anns.postfix: biosynthesis by repressing the expression of adjacent lodA–lodC, which seems to serve as an alternative regulatory system in addition to the conserved LodR2-LodE and LodR3 systems.

anns.prefix: For
anns.postfix: production, a suitable number of spores (~2.5 × 106) of Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172-WT, wild-type S. lasalocidi ATCC 31180T, or their mutants was inoculated into a 50-mL centrifuge tube containing 10 mL of liquid tryptic soy broth (TSB) (pancreatic digest of 1.7% casein and papaic digest of 0.3% soybean, 0.25% dextrose, 0.5% NaCl, and 0.25% K2HPO4 [pH 7.1 to 7.5]) and incubated on a rotary shaker at 220 rpm at 28°C for 48 h as a seed culture.

anns.prefix: For the analysis of
anns.postfix: , 50 mL of fermentation broth was centrifuged at 5,000 rpm for 15 min to separate the mycelia and the supernatant.

anns.prefix: Tandem mass spectrometry identification of
anns.postfix: was performed as previously described (26).

anns.prefix: The
anns.postfix: standard was used as a positive control for HPLC and mass spectrometry analyses to confirm the production of lasalocid (Fig. S6).

anns.prefix: KEYWORDS INTRODUCTION INTRODUCTION Actinobacteria, as the most abundant producers of secondary metabolites, produce a variety of complex
anns.postfix: with broad-spectrum biological activities (1).

anns.prefix: Among them, polyether ionophores are a unique class of type I
anns.postfix: featuring distinctive tetrahydrofuran and tetrahydropyran rings and are produced exclusively by actinobacteria.

anns.prefix: These
anns.postfix: have been successfully used in veterinary medicine and animal husbandry for more than half a century.

anns.prefix: The biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) of
anns.postfix: ericin (nig) and salinomycin (sln) both contain a single pathway-specific regulatory gene, and the overexpression of these genes greatly enhanced the production of the corresponding polyether ionophores (11, 12).

anns.prefix: The biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) of nigericin (nig) and salinomycin (
anns.postfix: ) both contain a single pathway-specific regulatory gene, and the overexpression of these genes greatly enhanced the production of the corresponding polyether ionophores (11, 12).

anns.prefix: Unlike
anns.postfix: and sln, the BGCs of monensin (mon) and nanchangmycin (nan) each contain multiple regulatory genes that encode regulators belonging to diverse families, including LAL (large ATP-binding regulators of the LuxR family), SARP (Streptomyces antibiotic regulatory proteins), TetR, and AraC. These regulators form complex coregulatory cascades governing the biosynthesis of monensin and nanchangmycin (13, 14).

anns.prefix: Based on the above-described regulatory studies, high-yield lasalocid-producing strains were constructed by overexpressing
anns.postfix: in the Δlas3 mutant via a multicopy vector, pKC1139::PkasO*las4, or a single-site integrative vector, pSET152::PkasO*las4.

anns.prefix: The resultant mutants, Δlas3-1139-
anns.postfix: and Δlas3-152-las4OE, enhanced their lasalocid yields by 5.1 and 6.8 times, respectively, compared to 31180-WT (Fig. 7A).

anns.prefix: Overall, by the simultaneous disruption of the negative regulatory gene
anns.postfix: and the overexpression of the positive regulatory gene las4, we obtained high-yield strains with lasalocid production of up to 230 mg/L. S. lasalocidi strains are used as industrially valuable lasalocid producers, and thus, the regulatory mechanism of their lasalocid biosynthesis is worth dissecting for the construction of high-yield strains.

anns.prefix: In this study, we demonstrate that lasalocid specifically binds to the MarR family transcription repressor LodR2 and causes its dissociation from the promoter region of
anns.postfix: (Fig. 5B), thus activating the transcription of lodE. This finding coincides with the defining feature of MarR family regulators: they normally respond to specific ligands, resulting in attenuated DNA-binding activity and often the derepression of target gene transcription (38).

anns.prefix: In this study, we demonstrate that lasalocid specifically binds to the MarR family transcription repressor LodR2 and causes its dissociation from the promoter region of lodR2–
anns.postfix: (Fig. 5B), thus activating the transcription of lodE. This finding coincides with the defining feature of MarR family regulators: they normally respond to specific ligands, resulting in attenuated DNA-binding activity and often the derepression of target gene transcription (38).

The transporter LodE is also crucial for lasalocid biosynthesis because disruption of
anns.postfix: results in reduced lasalocid production and an increased ratio of intracellular/extracellular lasalocid concentrations.

anns.postfix: sp. FXJ1.172, while lodR2 plays a negative regulatory role.

anns.prefix: Intriguingly, the variable gene locus lodR1–lodC from Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172 seems functionally conserved when introduced into
Here, we characterize the roles of regulatory genes in lasalocid biosynthetic gene clusters of two distinct
anns.postfix: species and identify a conserved repressor-activator system, LodR2–LodE, which could sense changes in the concentration of lasalocid and coordinate its biosynthesis with self-resistance.

anns.prefix: Furthermore, in parallel, we verify that the regulatory system identified in a new
anns.postfix: isolate is valid in the industrial lasalocid producer and thus applicable for the construction of high-yield strains.

anns.prefix: Unlike nig and sln, the BGCs of monensin (mon) and nanchangmycin (nan) each contain multiple regulatory genes that encode regulators belonging to diverse families, including LAL (large ATP-binding regulators of the LuxR family), SARP (
anns.postfix: antibiotic regulatory proteins), TetR, and AraC. These regulators form complex coregulatory cascades governing the biosynthesis of monensin and nanchangmycin (13, 14).

In our previous study, we identified a 76,167-bp putative lasalocid gene cluster (lod [GenBank accession number KT591188]) from the genome sequence of

Bioinformatics analysis revealed that the cluster contains 22 open reading frames (ORFs), designated lodA–lodT. In this study, to unravel the regulatory mechanism of lasalocid biosynthesis in different
anns.postfix: species, we first compared lod with the other two lasalocid gene clusters (las and lsd from S. lasalocidi strains).

Three genes of the lod cluster are proposed to play a regulatory role in lasalocid biosynthesis in
anns.postfix: , including a variable gene (lodR1) and two conserved ones (lodR2 and lodR3).

anns.prefix: To verify the functions of these genes, we constructed their mutants by disruptive in-frame deletions in the
anns.postfix: wild type (FXJ1.172-WT) and designated them ΔlodR1, ΔlodR2, and ΔlodR3, respectively.

anns.prefix: These results indicate that lodR1 and lodR3 positively regulate lasalocid biosynthesis in
anns.postfix: , while lodR2 plays a negative regulatory role.

Although the lodR1–lodC locus was found only in Streptomyces sp. FXJ1.172, we speculate that it might also function in heterologous lasalocid producers.

anns.prefix: To test this speculation, the lodA–lodC and lodR1–lodC loci were heterologously expressed in
anns.postfix: to generate strains 31180-KABC and 31180-R1ABC, respectively.

anns.prefix: These findings suggest that the variable genes lodR1 and lodA–lodC seem to function conservatively in lasalocid biosynthesis in different
anns.postfix: species.

anns.prefix: As las and lsd are very similar clusters from the same species, we then selected las (which is from the publicly available
anns.postfix: type strain) to compare the functions of its regulatory genes with those in lod.

anns.prefix: To verify the role of these genes in lasalocid biosynthesis, the corresponding disruption mutants (Δlas2, Δlas3, and Δlas4) were constructed from the
anns.postfix: wild type (31180-WT).

anns.prefix: Likewise, RT-qPCR analysis of las genes in 31180-WT and the disruption mutants displayed transcriptional patterns similar to those observed for lod genes in
anns.postfix: sp. FXJ1.172 (Fig. 7C).

anns.prefix: Analysis of the binding sites revealed an 8-bp palindromic sequence near the las2 TSP (consensus, 5′-CATTMRTT-3′ [where M is C or A and R is A or G]) (Fig. 7D), which is similar to the 5′-CATTCRT-3′ (where R is A or G) sequence found in the lodR2–lodE intergenic region from
anns.postfix: sp. FXJ1.172.

anns.prefix: All of these results are consistent with those for
anns.postfix: sp. FXJ1.172, indicating a conserved regulatory mechanism of lasalocid biosynthesis in the two species.

anns.prefix: Overall, by the simultaneous disruption of the negative regulatory gene las3 and the overexpression of the positive regulatory gene las4, we obtained high-yield strains with lasalocid production of up to 230 mg/L.

anns.prefix: Our results reveal that lasalocid biosynthesis in different
anns.postfix: species is controlled by one variable and two conserved regulatory systems, providing an understanding of the regulatory diversification and mechanism.

anns.prefix: The presence of this variable locus in
anns.postfix: could be partially ascribed to the divergent evolution of the regulation of lasalocid biosynthesis among streptomycetes.

anns.prefix: The distant phylogenetic relationship between
anns.postfix: and S. lasalocidi (96.2% 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity and 81.7% genome-wide average nucleotide identity) (24) and their disparate soil origins, red soil in China (25) and park soil in the United States (34), respectively, both support the divergent-evolution hypothesis.

anns.prefix: For lasalocid production, a suitable number of spores (~2.5 × 106) of
anns.postfix: , wild-type S. lasalocidi ATCC 31180T, or their mutants was inoculated into a 50-mL centrifuge tube containing 10 mL of liquid tryptic soy broth (TSB) (pancreatic digest of 1.7% casein and papaic digest of 0.3% soybean, 0.25% dextrose, 0.5% NaCl, and 0.25% K2HPO4 [pH 7.1 to 7.5]) and incubated on a rotary shaker at 220 rpm at 28°C for 48 h as a seed culture.
